title: Registration & Coffee
description: Get your badge, coffee, enjoy networking

title: Lunch
description: Get some yummy food and enjoy moar networking

title: Beacons, Hinting, and You: Context and Discovery
description: Letting your application know what's around you is hard. aGPS can be deceiving and work poorly indoors and the context of user is even more difficult to determine. With BLE beacons such as Eddystone, we can make our applications smarter. In this talk, I explore what exactly beacons are, how we can use them to hint and progressively enhance our users experience.

speakers.name: Justin Ribeiro
speakers.title: Software Engineer
speakers.bio: For the last 18 years, Justin has worked on enterprise and consumer-based software products – and is no stranger to building and deploying large-scale architecture for users in the field. As an early Google Glass Explorer, he has also worked extensively on integrating existing services with the platform – from real-time warehouse tracking to in-the-field sensor tracking for use in water management within agricultural operations. When Justin isn't building for Glass and Wear, he can be found building for Android and the web. Justin has successfully helped many startups bring concepts and ideas to market, and developed new internal systems to help even established companies become more efficient. Right now, Justin works at Stickman Ventures, managing software development teams on the US West Coast and overseas. He is also a co-organiser at GDG Oakdale, where he teaches and speaks on a wide range of Google technologies. He also spends time wiring and coding the Oakdale OpenMesh – a community-driven open wifi network. He lives in Oakdale with his wife, three daughters, and darkroom stockpile of HC-110.

title: Android Intents - Building a Public API on the Phone
description: With Android, you have the ability to expose functionality of your app to other apps. Sharing content like images, or text is common, but you can do a lot more. This presentation will walk through a couple of examples, and discuss how this might be used to build something interesting.

speakers.name: John Feig
speakers.title: Software Engineer
speakers.bio: Google Developer Expert for Wearables (Google Glass and Android Wear) and Software Engineer at TiKL, Inc. I get to do lots of fun stuff at TiKL, like writing clients for new platforms from scratch, and touching the full stack. I have worked on the Android client, the Java servers, a web client, a bit of PhotoShop, as well as keeping up with TiKL's social media presence. My goal as a GDE is to help people write solid code, and help them to really wrap their heads around the platform.

title: Building an Android chat app with Firebase
description: Come learn how Firebase can power your Android app's backend. Firebase takes care of the stuff every app needs including data storage, user authentication, and hosting. This lets you focus on creating extraordinary user experiences instead of building a back end. </br></br>In this code lab a team of Google Developer Advocates will guide you through the process of building a chat application using Firebase and Android Studio. </br></br>This talk is an introduction to Firebase, but it assumes that you're already comfortable writing simple Android apps. Please come with Android Studio installed and your Android device ready to go.

speakers.name: Jenny Tong
speakers.title: Developer Advocate
speakers.bio: Jenny is a Developer Advocate on Cloud at Google. In this role she helps developers build cool stuff on all sorts of platforms. Previously she worked in a wide variety of software roles from robotics at NASA, to developer advocacy for Google Glass. She is passionate about education, especially on the subjects of technology and science. If she's away from her laptop, she's probably skating around a roller derby track, or hanging from aerial silk.

title: Building Web Sites that Work Everywhere
description: How to build web sites that work well across various browsers versions and devices is always challenging for web developers. In the session, you’ll learn the best practices and strategy to develop cross-browser web sites that will work with the existing and future browsers. Tools for interoperability tests, cross-browser fundamentals, and tips and tricks on HTML5, CSS, JavaScript development will be illustrated.  Feature detection, CSS prefix, and fallbacks will all be examined in the session. A real life example will be used to demonstrate step by step how to build cross-browser and plug-in-Free experiences. With a couple of simple changes to your sites, you can take advantage of web standards and HTML5 features today without breaking your sites in the future. Expect a lot of demos and code in the session.

speakers.name: Doris Chen
speakers.title: Senior Technology Evangelist
speakers.bio: Dr. Doris Chen is a Senior Technology Evangelist at Microsoft for the Western region of the United States, specialized in web technologies (HTML5, jQuery, JavaScript, Ajax, and Java). Doris has over 18 years of experience in the software industry working in several open source web tier technologies, Java platform, .NET and distributed computing technologies. She has developed and delivered over 400 keynotes, technical sessions, and trainings worldwide. She speaks at numerous international conferences and user groups including O’Reilly OSCON, Fluent, Dev Nexus, HTML5 Dev Conference, WebVisions,  JavaOne, SD Forum, and worldwide User Groups. Doris works very closely to create and foster the open source community around Java, NetBeans, Glassfish, and related technologies. Before joining Microsoft, Doris Chen was a Technology Evangelist at Sun Microsystems. Doris received her Ph.D. from the University of California at Los Angeles (UCLA) in computer engineering, specializing in medical informatics.

title: Let's play Dart!
description: In this session you will explore how to write your first server-side Dart application. Come to this workshop to try and learn Dart, have fun and see how you can write awesome applications and be productive with it. Note: please don't forget to bring your laptop with downloaded Dart and some editor/IDE with Dart support. More info: https://www.dartlang.org/downloads/.

speakers.name: Jana Moudrá
speakers.title: Co-Founder
speakers.bio:
GDE (Google Developer Expert) for Dart. Jana is a passionate developer and modern web and mobile technology evangelist. She is an event organiser for GDG Prague, where she arranges events for developers including public lectures, code labs and hackathons – covering a wide range of subjects including technologies Dart or Android. She loves to help other developers and spread the knowledge about these technologies.

Jana co-founded a company called Juicymo, where she works on juicy apps and products and teaches at Unicorn College.

title: Looking Under The Hood of Chrome DevTools
description: Chrome DevTools are arguably the most important position in every front-end developers toolset. They are used by 25 million users worldwide. But how do they work? Let's break them open and see!

speakers.name: Konrad Dzwinel
speakers.title: Senior Front-End Developer
speakers.bio: Konrad is a front-end developer at Brainly, Google Developer Expert for Web Technologies and co-organizer of Google Developers Group in Krakow, Poland. Over the years he worked for various startups, consultancies and software houses building websites, hybrid apps and internal tools. After work, he develops Chrome extensions, experiments with various front-end technologies, gives presentations and runs workshops.

title: The power of Dataflow
description: Dealing with massive datasets can be a real chore. The biggest pain point is setting up, and maintaining the infrastructure. However, that's now changing with the emergence of cloud products like Dataflow. Pablo will jump into this brand new product from Google, and show how it let's you focus on your code, rather than worrying about the infrastructure needed to work with big data. He'll talk about how you can use it to clean, and analyze your data with ease, and how Dataflow will spin up & tear down VM clusters for your data pipelines on the fly!

speakers.name: Pablo Caif
speakers.title: Software engineer
speakers.bio: Pablo is a passionate software engineer who enjoys solving complex problems, and devising simple solutions. He works at Shine Technologies and he is part of a team that uses BigQuery and Dataflow to solve challenging and complex data processing business requirements. Pablo considers that scalability and performance are paramount to developing a great solution, and that is why he has been using Dataflow and BigQuery to bring these solutions to reality.

title: Reeling in big data using Google BigQuery
description: Managing infrastructure, worrying about scalability, and waiting for queries to finish executing are some of the biggest challenges when working with massive volumes of data. One solution is to outsource the heavy lifting to someone else, thereby allowing you to spend more time on actually analyzing, and drawing insights out of your data. Google want to be that someone else! Part of their big data product lineup, BigQuery is a bleeding edge SaaS that is designed to make it easy for users to get up and running without the need to care about operational overheads. In this presentation, Graham will give an introduction to BigQuery, and show how it can be used to query terabytes and billions of rows in ridiculously fast times. He'll cover its core features, cost model, available APIs, and caveats. Finally, he'll show how they used BigQuery at a recent project for Australia's largest ISP, and give a quick demo of BigQuery in action.

speakers.name: Graham Polley
speakers.title: Senior Software Engineer
speakers.bio: Graham is a senior software engineer based out of Melbourne Australia. He's passionate about promoting the adoption of cloud technologies into software development, and regularly blogs and gives presentations. Graham has extensive experience in building big data solutions for clients using the Google technology stack, and in particular with BigQuery & Dataflow. Graham works very closely with the GCP engineering team in the US, where he is a member of their cloud platform trusted tester program, and the solutions he helps build are used as internal exemplars of developer use cases. Graham is also a GDE on the GCP.

title: Whisper Dungeon for Google Cardboard
description: Design and develop for Virtual Reality is different than just making apps for a mobile device. We get extra depth and more complexity in control. In this talk, we will demo some VR games and talk about the process of making them.

speakers.name: Macy Kuang
speakers.title: Founder
speakers.bio: Macy is the founder of Miaomiao Games, GDE for Wearables, host at Code to Create and organizer for AndroidTO conference. She is passionate about gaming and IOT.

title: How Google can help your career in technology

speakers.name: Martin Omander
speakers.title: Program Manager for Google Developer Relations

title: Let's Play! - Intro to Google Cardboard
description: When I started making a Cardboard App, I had a lot to learn. I didn't know much about OpenGL, things kept breaking when I changed little details... it was painful. Not being a very sensible person, I kept going, and I'd like to share with you some of the things I found out.

speakers.name: Etienne Caron
speakers.title: Senior Mobile Developer / Android Lead
speakers.bio: Etienne has been an active member of the Android developer community in Montreal since 2010, and regularly devotes his time towards mentoring startups, developers and students in the mobile space. As part of the Montreal Android GDG, he organises meetups, hackathons, and gives regular talks on Android-related subjects. He's now part of the Google Developer Expert program.

title: Hacking your idea together in 24 hours
description: Ever wanted to develop an idea for an application or website? Learn techniques of how to quickly prototype your idea into a working application at a 24 hour hackathon.

speakers.name: JeanCarl Bisson
speakers.title: Technical Evangelist
speakers.bio: JeanCarl Bisson is a Technical Evangelist for IBM Bluemix. He has participated in over 100 hackathon over the last six years, winning prizes and cash. He has taken several hacks to market. He loves to quickly build prototypes and see how they work out.

title: Angular — Introduction to Reactive Extensions (RxJS)
description: Reactive Extensions for JavaScript (RxJS) is a reactive streams library that allows you to work with multiple asynchronous data streams (aka Observable sequences). Angular 2 http new module favours Rx over Promises. We are going to explore what is RxJS all about and how we can use it in Angular.

speakers.name: Gerard Sans
speakers.title: Software Developer
speakers.bio: Gerard is a multi-talented Computer Science Engineer specialised in Web. He is now an AngularJS fanboy and a community activist fighting for the JavaScript revolution. He has lived and worked for all sorts of companies in Germany, Brazil, UK and Spain. He is always up for a good challenge. He enjoys running AngularJS Labs London, mentoring AngularJS students, participating in the community, giving talks and writing technical articles at Medium.

title: Google Fit and Android Wear the perfect match for fitness apps

speakers.name: Matias Molinas
speakers.title: Software Developer
speakers.bio:
Matias is an experienced software architect, designer, and developer. He has worked on multiple projects, including consumer, enterprise, and medical software products and applications.
He's currently working as a Java Architect on an eCommerce platform for Project ARA. The project will enable users to create a modular smartphone that's precisely tailored to their functional and aesthetic preferences. Since 2011, Matias has been a Google Developer Expert for YouTube APIs.
As an independent entrepreneur, Matias is also currently involved in a new platform for mobile application and wearable technology – and has previously run a startup venture related to smart video and social content recommendation engine, and in an ads optimisation tool. He was a consultant for the University of Nebraska too – for a project in computer aided surgery, addressing design, 3D-tracking, and 3D-visualization aspects.
At college, Matias studied Biomedical Engineering at the UNER in Argentina – where he lives with his wife and two children. When time allows, he enjoys playing water polo.

title: JDXA, The KISS ORM for Android
description: JDXA is a simple, non-intrusive, and flexible Object Relational Mapping (ORM) product that dramatically decreases development time by presenting a more intuitive object-oriented view of on-device SQLite relational data, eliminating the need to write and maintain endless lines of complex low-level SQL code. This presentation will provide an overview of JDXA with code snippets.

speakers.name: Damodar Periwal
speakers.title: Software Engineer, Founder
speakers.bio: Damodar Periwal has an extensive background in databases, transaction processing, as well as distributed and object-oriented technologies. Damodar has more than 25 years of industry experience, having worked at leading companies like Google, TIBCO, Borland, Ashton-Tate, and Tandem Computers. Damodar has an MS (Computer Science) degree from University of Wisconsin (Madison) and an undergraduate engineering degree from Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani (India).

title: Android and the Seven Dwarfs
description: This talk will focus on seven great opensource libraries which do fix Android's programming model, the way jquery fixes javascript. The libraries below will be covered with example code, advantages, disadvantages, internals and when to use them.

speakers.name: Murat Yener
speakers.title: Android Developer
speakers.bio:
Murat Yener is a code geek, open source committer and working in Intel as an Android Developer. He has extensive experience on developing Java, Web, JavaEE and OSGi applications besides teaching courses and mentoring. Murat is an Eclipse committer and one of the initial committers of Eclipse Libra project. He is currently working on building native and Hybrid mobile apps with mGWT.
He is the author of upcoming Professional Java EE Design Patterns book from Wiley. He has been a user group leader at GDG Istanbul since 2009. Murat is a regular speaker at conferences like JavaOne, EclipseCon and user group meetings.

title: Wearing Jacquard Android
description: A review of the current Google Project Jacquard and Project Soli with respect to Android Wear. This presentation will show how these projects will revolutionize wearables.

speakers.name: Siamak Ashrafi
speakers.title: Researcher/Developer
speakers.bio: Ash is a researcher TDI working on medical biomarkers (scientific publications) & CTO Zoewear building physiologically intelligent clothing (technology patents).  His frequent code-a-thon wins have gone on to become published Apps (iOS & Android).  As a thought leader in wearable/mobile development he is an enthusiastic teacher/speaker helping to promote the ecosystem (fashion & technology).  You can usually catch him DJ or competing in one of the phases of water. (Snowboarding [solid], Surfing [liquid] & Kiteboarding [vapor].

title: Kaleidoscope with Dataflow
description: Possibilities of discerning data patterns with data flow cloud scale data parallelism.

speakers.name: Latha Krishnaswamy
speakers.title: Researcher/Developer
speakers.bio: Software development expertise, entrepreneur enthusiast in new software development.

title: Speed with Ease, NoSQL on GCP
description: Lessons learned from running benchmark tests with the Aerospike team using Google Cloud Platform (GCP) virtual machines.

speakers.name: Lynn Langit
speakers.title: Independent Cloud and Big Data Architect
speakers.bio: Big Data and Cloud Architect - AWS Community Hero, Google Cloud Developer Expert, Microsoft MVP. Author of Lynda.com, Pluralsight, Wintellect and DevelopMentor courseware. YouTube BigData playlist. Over 250k people have watched my 'Hadoop Fundamentals' courses online.

title: Go Programming
description: An Introduction to the Go Programming Language

speakers.name: Todd McLeod
speakers.title: Faculty
speakers.bio: Todd McLeod is Faculty in Computer Science at California State University, Fresno. He is also faculty at Fresno City College.

title: Rapid Deployment & Strategies for launching a browser extension in a startup
description: SalesforceIQ's Chrome extension provides contextual information and productivity features inside Gmail, in order to seamlessly provide CRM access and enhance users' email workflow. Since the launch, we have delivered 10+ features in the Chrome extension in one year to become one of the highest engagement product. In this talk, we will cover the basics of a Chrome extension, deep-diving on the "read receipts" feature, and how we architected RelateIQ Chrome extension to enable rapid deployment and code-sharing. All these lessons can be transferred to startups launching a browser extension client.

speakers.name: Keven Wang
speakers.title: Senior Technical Staff
speakers.bio: Keven Wang is a Senior Member of Technical Staff at SalesforceIQ, where he leads the Chrome extension project, building it from zero into the fastest-growing client at RelateIQ. On this journey, Keven architected Chrome extension to enable rapid deployment and code-sharing with RelateIQ's web-app client using AngularJS. Keven has delivered 10+ features in Chrome extension in 12 months, leveraging backend infrastructure on email / calendar sync (IMAP, Google Calendar API) and push notifications (Google Cloud Messaging). Keven joined RelateIQ in 2013, prior to its acquisition by Salesforce in 2014.

title: Multi-Language Multi-services in Google Cloud
description: One of greatest benefit with multi-service architecture is being able to develop different platforms/languages. In this presentation I will show how to unite different languages - NodeJS, GoLang and Dart - in single application hosted in Google Cloud Platform.

speakers.name: Valentyn Shybanov
speakers.title: Software Engineer
speakers.bio:
Started software engineering career with low level system programming mostly on start of the era of modern computers, my interest involved from programming calculators and simple games to developing complex enterprise-level cloud-based solutions. Now, with help of modern technologies, solutions and concepts, I am not just trying to bring any, even most courageous ideas into life, but also spread the light of all brilliant technology solutions I can find to all other developers. Now focused on combination of Web technologies (AngularJS, Dart) and cloud platforms (Google Cloud Platform, Amazon EC2, Azure etc).
Currently I am Google Developer Expert (Cloud and Web) and Software Architect of Twinfield International N.V. and building online accounting system and responsible for making architectural decisions for bringing Twinfield application into cloud. Also part of Wolter’s Kluwer’s European PaaS initiative (building enterprise-level PaaS solution to unify development environment for different WK companies).

title: Develop and Design for Android Marshmallow
description:
The latest version of Android contains many significant changes from previous versions. Attend the Fireside Chats to hear a panel of Google Developer Experts discuss the most important changes, and the steps you should take to incorporate them into your Android apps.
This special event will include a lively discussion on Marshmallow's latest features and how to best take advantage of them. Also come ready with questions and suggestions of your own!
We have gathered a great collection of Google Developer Experts to answer your questions, including Said Tahsin Dane, Chiu-Ki Chan, Ryan Harter, Wiebe Elsinga, and Mike Wolfson.
If you would like to ask a question ahead of time, please use this G+ link: https://plus.google.com/+MichaelWolfson/posts/hdLh3npNUEg

speakers.name: Mike Wolfson
speakers.title: Independent Android Developer
speakers.bio: Mike is a senior-level Android\Java developer with a proven history of success and a long list of accomplishments. He's also a great developer, an excellent communicator and leader, and has a comprehensive knowledge of the full life-cycle of mobile-focused development and design. Mike's a passionate coder too, with an eye for simplicity – and a love for writing beautiful, pragmatic, code.

title: Grand Challenges of Hyperscale Hyperconvergence Big Data Cloud Autotomation Powered by Software-Defined-Infrastructure when Moore's Law Does Not Matter Anymore
description: The enterprise is being consumerized, and the consumer is being enterprised. Moore's Law does not matter anymore, the future belongs to business virtualization powered by invisible service architecture, powered by hyperscale and hyperconvergence, and facilitated by vertical streaming and horizontal scaling and consolidation. Both buyers and sellers want instant results, and from paperwork to paperless to mindless is the ultimate goal for any seamless transaction. The sweetest sweet spot in innovation is automation. The most painful pain point for any business is the mismatch between supplies and demands instead of information asymmetry as before. The distinction between web-scale and enterprise-grade infrastructures has been diminishing, cloud computing and Big Data are being driven by each other, and there is no silver bullet one size fits all.

speakers.name: Forbes Hedges
speakers.bio: Cloudata Czar and CloudBnB Marketplace Builder and Operator (www.hwswworld.com), has accumulated over 20 years of experience in automation, which is part of his passion instead of career. He started his career in the EDA industry working for two public companies on chip design automation before he started his own startup journey as a self-taught businessman by bootstrapping a few startups including Cloudata Inc.
